channel.title: Python
channel.description: Should I learn it. I want to start web designing again, and am wondering if it's a useful language to learn.

item.title: Python
item.dc:creator: @imthenull imthenull
item.description:
@imthenull wrote:

I agree with you, i think it’s practically essential for any web developer to know PHP.

Read full topic

item.title: Python
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

[quote=“RSCShadow, post:12, topic:476016”][quote author=justaguy link=topic=594164.msg4188644#msg4188644 date=1356551650]

[quote author=RSCShadow link=topic=594164.msg4188625#msg4188625 date=1356550195]

[quote=justaguy]Atleast with PHP you get more lower-level with working on the server-side than with Python and Django.[/quote]What are you talking about?

OT: Python is a lot nicer and more consistent language than PHP.

Code-wise, because with Django the MVC architecture is already built and alot of stuff such as working with sessions, etc. is abstracted in classes whereas PHP doesn’t have this (hence why Django is a FRAMEWORK so of course it is going to be HIGHER-LEVEL than PHP itself). Instead, PHP is a set of loosely organized procedural functions that allow you to do this.

Note that I don’t actually use Django, but of course because it is a framework it is going to be more abstracted… I would expect you to already know this concept RSCShadow…
[/quote]Why does this matter though? Why is it a plus? Like you said it’s all loosely organized and pretty messy so why would you rather work with it instead of a well-structured framework?

Also it’s worth mentioning that PHP also has frameworks available (obviously), but that doesn’t fix the flaws with the language.

Might not necessarily be a plus, but for someone interested in the web it may be helpful.

Now, let me point out that I’m not against frameworks at all. Libraries like Django seem interesting, and I’ve used PHP libraries such as CodeIgniter and I’m impressed because they do a great job. I’m not trying to degrade Django and Python, considering I am also starting to get into Python more lately (see my post above with issues relating to my webhost).

And I totally agree that PHP is very flawed in many ways, but I still personally like it.
[/quote]Yes then that’s fair. Working with messy programming languages may help them appreciate the better ones.[/quote]

Not to mention I would probably expect most web developers to have knowledge in PHP because it’s so widely used.

Read full topic

item.title: Python
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“justaguy, post:11, topic:476016”][quote author=RSCShadow link=topic=594164.msg4188625#msg4188625 date=1356550195]

[quote=justaguy]Atleast with PHP you get more lower-level with working on the server-side than with Python and Django.[/quote]What are you talking about?

OT: Python is a lot nicer and more consistent language than PHP.

Code-wise, because with Django the MVC architecture is already built and alot of stuff such as working with sessions, etc. is abstracted in classes whereas PHP doesn’t have this (hence why Django is a FRAMEWORK so of course it is going to be HIGHER-LEVEL than PHP itself). Instead, PHP is a set of loosely organized procedural functions that allow you to do this.

Note that I don’t actually use Django, but of course because it is a framework it is going to be more abstracted… I would expect you to already know this concept RSCShadow…
[/quote]Why does this matter though? Why is it a plus? Like you said it’s all loosely organized and pretty messy so why would you rather work with it instead of a well-structured framework?

Also it’s worth mentioning that PHP also has frameworks available (obviously), but that doesn’t fix the flaws with the language.

Might not necessarily be a plus, but for someone interested in the web it may be helpful.

Now, let me point out that I’m not against frameworks at all. Libraries like Django seem interesting, and I’ve used PHP libraries such as CodeIgniter and I’m impressed because they do a great job. I’m not trying to degrade Django and Python, considering I am also starting to get into Python more lately (see my post above with issues relating to my webhost).

And I totally agree that PHP is very flawed in many ways, but I still personally like it. :)[/quote]Yes then that’s fair. Working with messy programming languages may help them appreciate the better ones.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

[quote=“RSCShadow, post:10, topic:476016”][quote author=justaguy link=topic=594164.msg4188382#msg4188382 date=1356506183]

[quote=justaguy]Atleast with PHP you get more lower-level with working on the server-side than with Python and Django.[/quote]What are you talking about?

OT: Python is a lot nicer and more consistent language than PHP.

Code-wise, because with Django the MVC architecture is already built and alot of stuff such as working with sessions, etc. is abstracted in classes whereas PHP doesn’t have this (hence why Django is a FRAMEWORK so of course it is going to be HIGHER-LEVEL than PHP itself). Instead, PHP is a set of loosely organized procedural functions that allow you to do this.

Note that I don’t actually use Django, but of course because it is a framework it is going to be more abstracted… I would expect you to already know this concept RSCShadow…
[/quote]Why does this matter though? Why is it a plus? Like you said it’s all loosely organized and pretty messy so why would you rather work with it instead of a well-structured framework?

Also it’s worth mentioning that PHP also has frameworks available (obviously), but that doesn’t fix the flaws with the language.[/quote]

Might not necessarily be a plus, but for someone interested in the web it may be helpful.

Now, let me point out that I’m not against frameworks at all. Libraries like Django seem interesting, and I’ve used PHP libraries such as CodeIgniter and I’m impressed because they do a great job. I’m not trying to degrade Django and Python, considering I am also starting to get into Python more lately (see my post above with issues relating to my webhost).

And I totally agree that PHP is very flawed in many ways, but I still personally like it.

Read full topic

item.title: Python
item.dc:creator: @rash Rash
item.description:
@rash wrote:

[quote=“justaguy, post:6, topic:476016”][quote author=Rash link=topic=594164.msg4188286#msg4188286 date=1356494457]

Python is nowhere near as widely adopted as RoR unfortunately. Alot of the configuration for a framework like Django will probably require you to contact your host and have them configure it so you can have it used. Other than that, programming with Python on the web is very doable and is becoming more popular.

I actually just started a hosting package from a place that apparently offered “Python” for the webhosting users but couldn’t even configure mod_wsgi… Quite disappointing.

I see. So I should wait a bit?

What would you suggest learning after html and css?

Not necessarily. Just ask some questions in a sales chat even if the host claims to offer Python support.

As for using Python over PHP or RoR, I don’t know too much to give any insight on this. But if a large site like Instagram happens to use it; should be fine.

Ah, okay. I suppose I’ll try to learn PHP first, then move onto Python. Thanks for the advice!
[/quote]

That is a good idea. Atleast with PHP you get more lower-level with working on the server-side than with Python and Django.[/quote]

Alright, thanks!

Also, is using Dreamweaver recommended?

Read full topic

item.title: Python
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

[quote=“Rash, post:5, topic:476016”][quote author=justaguy link=topic=594164.msg4188266#msg4188266 date=1356493144]

Python is nowhere near as widely adopted as RoR unfortunately. Alot of the configuration for a framework like Django will probably require you to contact your host and have them configure it so you can have it used. Other than that, programming with Python on the web is very doable and is becoming more popular.

I actually just started a hosting package from a place that apparently offered “Python” for the webhosting users but couldn’t even configure mod_wsgi… Quite disappointing.

I see. So I should wait a bit?

What would you suggest learning after html and css?

Not necessarily. Just ask some questions in a sales chat even if the host claims to offer Python support.

As for using Python over PHP or RoR, I don’t know too much to give any insight on this. But if a large site like Instagram happens to use it; should be fine.
[/quote]

Ah, okay. I suppose I’ll try to learn PHP first, then move onto Python. Thanks for the advice![/quote]

That is a good idea. Atleast with PHP you get more lower-level with working on the server-side than with Python and Django.

Read full topic
